The center of mass of a finite subset of a convex set belongs to the set
provided that all weights are non-negative, and the total weight is positive.

type:
‚àÄ {R : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} {Œπ : Type u_5} [inst : LinearOrderedField R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : Module R E] {s : Set E} {t : Finset Œπ} {w : Œπ ‚Üí R} {z : Œπ ‚Üí E},
  Convex R s ‚Üí (‚àÄ i ‚àà t, 0 ‚â§ w i) ‚Üí (0 < Finset.sum t fun i => w i) ‚Üí (‚àÄ i ‚àà t, z i ‚àà s) ‚Üí Finset.centerMass t w z ‚àà s
name: Convex.centerMass_mem
docString:
The center of mass of a finite subset of a convex set belongs to the set
provided that all weights are non-negative, and the total weight is positive.

For all complex numbers x, Complex.exp x = Complex.cos x + Complex.i * Complex.sin x.

type: ‚àÄ (x : ‚ÑÇ), (x * Complex.I).exp = x.cos + x.sin * Complex.I
name: Complex.exp_mul_I
docString: For all complex numbers x, Complex.exp x = Complex.cos x + Complex.i * Complex.sin x.

This theorem states that the Schnirelmann density of a set of natural numbers is unaffected by the removal of the element `0`. In other words, for any set `A` of natural numbers, the Schnirelmann density of `A` and the Schnirelmann density of `A` without `0` are equal. The Schnirelmann density, defined as the infimum of the ratio of the cardinality of the intersection of `A` with the set `{1, ..., n}` to `n` as `n` ranges over the positive natural numbers, remains the same even if `0` is removed from set `A`. The predicates for membership in `A` and `A` without `0` are assumed to be decidable.

type:
‚àÄ {A : Set ‚Ñï} [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ‚àà A] [inst_1 : DecidablePred fun x => x ‚àà A \ {0}],
  schnirelmannDensity (A \ {0}) = schnirelmannDensity A
name: schnirelmannDensity_diff_singleton_zero
docString: This theorem states that the Schnirelmann density of a set of natural numbers is unaffected by the removal of the element `0`. In other words, for any set `A` of natural numbers, the Schnirelmann density of `A` and the Schnirelmann density of `A` without `0` are equal. The Schnirelmann density, defined as the infimum of the ratio of the cardinality of the intersection of `A` with the set `{1, ..., n}` to `n` as `n` ranges over the positive natural numbers, remains the same even if `0` is removed from set `A`. The predicates for membership in `A` and `A` without `0` are assumed to be decidable.

A map between two inner product spaces is a conformal map if and only if it preserves inner
products up to a scalar factor, i.e., there exists a positive `c : ‚Ñù` such that
`‚ü™f u, f v‚ü´ = c * ‚ü™u, v‚ü´` for all `u`, `v`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} {F : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_2 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_3 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù F] (f : E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F),
  IsConformalMap f ‚Üî ‚àÉ c, 0 < c ‚àß ‚àÄ (u v : E), ‚ü™f u, f v‚ü´_‚Ñù = c * ‚ü™u, v‚ü´_‚Ñù
name: isConformalMap_iff
docString:
A map between two inner product spaces is a conformal map if and only if it preserves inner
products up to a scalar factor, i.e., there exists a positive `c : ‚Ñù` such that
`‚ü™f u, f v‚ü´ = c * ‚ü™u, v‚ü´` for all `u`, `v`.

A set of natural numbers has Schnirelmann density equal to 1 if and only if it contains all positive natural numbers.

type: ‚àÄ {A : Set ‚Ñï} [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ‚àà A], schnirelmannDensity A = 1 ‚Üî {0}·∂ú ‚äÜ A
name: schnirelmannDensity_eq_one_iff
docString: A set of natural numbers has Schnirelmann density equal to 1 if and only if it contains all positive natural numbers.

This theorem states that in a metric space equipped with the "Besicovitch property", any set `s` can be covered with a countable collection of closed balls in such a way that the sum of the measures (sizes) of these balls is at most the measure of the set `s` plus any positive real number `Œµ`. This is true even when we restrict the possible radii of the balls centered at a point `x` to be within a set `f x` that gets arbitrarily close to `0`. Specifically, for every point `x` in `s`, we can always find a radius within the intersection of `f x` and the open interval from `0` to any positive number `Œ¥`, and we can then cover the set `s` with the closed balls centered at points in `t` (a subset of `s`) with these radii. The total measure of these balls will not exceed the measure of `s` plus `Œµ`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite Œº] [inst_6 : Œº.OuterRegular] {Œµ : ENNReal},
  Œµ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ (f : Œ± ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù) (s : Set Œ±),
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥).Nonempty) ‚Üí
        ‚àÉ t r,
          t.Countable ‚àß
            t ‚äÜ s ‚àß
              (‚àÄ x ‚àà t, r x ‚àà f x) ‚àß
                s ‚äÜ ‚ãÉ x ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall x (r x) ‚àß ‚àë' (x : ‚Üët), ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (Metric.closedBall (‚Üëx) (r ‚Üëx)) ‚â§ ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº s + Œµ
name: Besicovitch.exists_closedBall_covering_tsum_measure_le
docString: This theorem states that in a metric space equipped with the "Besicovitch property", any set `s` can be covered with a countable collection of closed balls in such a way that the sum of the measures (sizes) of these balls is at most the measure of the set `s` plus any positive real number `Œµ`. This is true even when we restrict the possible radii of the balls centered at a point `x` to be within a set `f x` that gets arbitrarily close to `0`. Specifically, for every point `x` in `s`, we can always find a radius within the intersection of `f x` and the open interval from `0` to any positive number `Œ¥`, and we can then cover the set `s` with the closed balls centered at points in `t` (a subset of `s`) with these radii. The total measure of these balls will not exceed the measure of `s` plus `Œµ`.

L'H√¥pital's rule for approaching +‚àû, `HasDerivAt` version

type:
‚àÄ {l : Filter ‚Ñù} {f f' g g' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù},
  (‚àÄ·∂† (x : ‚Ñù) in Filter.atTop, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ·∂† (x : ‚Ñù) in Filter.atTop, HasDerivAt g (g' x) x) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ·∂† (x : ‚Ñù) in Filter.atTop, g' x ‚â† 0) ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop (nhds 0) ‚Üí

            Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f' x / g' x) Filter.atTop l ‚Üí Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f x / g x) Filter.atTop l

docString: L'H√¥pital's rule for approaching +‚àû, `HasDerivAt` version

docString:
In a preconnected space, any disjoint cover by non-empty open subsets has at most one

In a space with the Besicovitch property, any set `s` can be covered with balls whose measures
add up to at most `Œº s + Œµ`, for any positive `Œµ`. This works even if one restricts the set of
allowed radii around a point `x` to a set `f x` which accumulates at `0`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite Œº] [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.Measure.OuterRegular Œº] {Œµ : ENNReal},
  Œµ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ (f : Œ± ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù) (s : Set Œ±),
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, Set.Nonempty (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥)) ‚Üí
        ‚àÉ t r,
          Set.Countable t ‚àß
            t ‚äÜ s ‚àß
              (‚àÄ x ‚àà t, r x ‚àà f x) ‚àß
                s ‚äÜ ‚ãÉ x ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall x (r x) ‚àß ‚àë' (x : ‚Üët), ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (Metric.closedBall (‚Üëx) (r ‚Üëx)) ‚â§ ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº s + Œµ
name: Besicovitch.exists_closedBall_covering_tsum_measure_le
docString:
In a space with the Besicovitch property, any set `s` can be covered with balls whose measures
add up to at most `Œº s + Œµ`, for any positive `Œµ`. This works even if one restricts the set of
allowed radii around a point `x` to a set `f x` which accumulates at `0`.

An equivalence of the index set defines an equivalence between the spaces of continuous
multilinear maps. In case of normed spaces, this is a linear isometric equivalence, see
`ContinuousMultilinearMap.domDomCongr‚Çó·µ¢`.

type:
{R : Type u} ‚Üí
  {Œπ : Type v} ‚Üí
    {M‚ÇÇ : Type w‚ÇÇ} ‚Üí
      {M‚ÇÉ : Type w‚ÇÉ} ‚Üí
        [inst : Semiring R] ‚Üí
          [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M‚ÇÇ] ‚Üí
            [inst_2 : AddCommMonoid M‚ÇÉ] ‚Üí
              [inst_3 : Module R M‚ÇÇ] ‚Üí
                [inst_4 : Module R M‚ÇÉ] ‚Üí
                  [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace M‚ÇÇ] ‚Üí
                    [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M‚ÇÉ] ‚Üí
                      {Œπ' : Type u_1} ‚Üí
                        Œπ ‚âÉ Œπ' ‚Üí
                          ContinuousMultilinearMap R (fun x => M‚ÇÇ) M‚ÇÉ ‚âÉ ContinuousMultilinearMap R (fun x => M‚ÇÇ) M‚ÇÉ
name: ContinuousMultilinearMap.domDomCongrEquiv
docString:
An equivalence of the index set defines an equivalence between the spaces of continuous
multilinear maps. In case of normed spaces, this is a linear isometric equivalence, see
`ContinuousMultilinearMap.domDomCongr‚Çó·µ¢`.

Center of mass of a finite collection of points with prescribed weights.
Note that we require neither `0 ‚â§ w i` nor `‚àë w = 1`.

{R : Type u_1} ‚Üí
  {E : Type u_3} ‚Üí
    {Œπ : Type u_5} ‚Üí
      [inst : LinearOrderedField R] ‚Üí [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] ‚Üí [inst : Module R E] ‚Üí Finset Œπ ‚Üí (Œπ ‚Üí R) ‚Üí (Œπ ‚Üí E) ‚Üí E

Center of mass of a finite collection of points with prescribed weights.

A convex combination of two centers of mass is a center of mass as well. This version
works if two centers of mass share the set of original points.

type:
‚àÄ {R : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} {Œπ : Type u_5} [inst : LinearOrderedField R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : Module R E] (s : Finset Œπ) (w‚ÇÅ w‚ÇÇ : Œπ ‚Üí R) (z : Œπ ‚Üí E),
  (Finset.sum s fun i => w‚ÇÅ i) = 1 ‚Üí
    (Finset.sum s fun i => w‚ÇÇ i) = 1 ‚Üí
      ‚àÄ (a b : R),
        a + b = 1 ‚Üí
          a ‚Ä¢ Finset.centerMass s w‚ÇÅ z + b ‚Ä¢ Finset.centerMass s w‚ÇÇ z =
            Finset.centerMass s (fun i => a * w‚ÇÅ i + b * w‚ÇÇ i) z
name: Finset.centerMass_segment
docString:
A convex combination of two centers of mass is a center of mass as well. This version
works if two centers of mass share the set of original points.
